title: Global monitoring of vegetation conditions and GPP from 30 years of passive microwave observations
abstract: &lt;div&gt; &lt;p&gt;&lt;span&gt;Microwave radiation emitted by the Earth surface is&amp;#160;attenuated by vegetation. The magnitude of attenuation is commonly referred to as Vegetation Optical Depth (VOD) and depends on several factors, such as the water content of the vegetation and the wavelength of the sensor. It can be derived from space-borne microwave radiometers and has been explored for multiple applications including drought and biomass monitoring. Here, we present two&amp;#160;novel applications based on long-term multi-satellite observations of VOD: 1) the Standardized VOD Index (SVODI) for&amp;#160;monitoring vegetation condition and 2) modelling Gross Primary Production (VODCA2GPP). &lt;/span&gt;&lt;span&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt; &lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt; &lt;p&gt;&lt;span&gt;SVODI [1] is a standard normally distributed index indicating the condition of vegetation.&amp;#160;Traditional index generation methods struggle to combine data from multiple data sources and often either exhibit a changing variance over time due to changing input sensors, or are biased. We solve these issues with a new probabilistic merging method, which in principle can be applied to other datasets as well. We show that SVODI, which is an indicator of vegetation structure, biomass and water content, supplements existing vegetation condition indexes based on optical data, which mostly represent the greenness of the vegetation. In the presentation, we also assess spatio-temporal patterns and trends of extreme SVODI values.&lt;/span&gt;&lt;span&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt; &lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt; &lt;p&gt;&lt;span&gt;VODCA2GPP [2] is a global GPP dataset derived from VOD using a sink-driven approach. It uses a machine learning framework using the VOD Climate Archive (VODCA), a long-term coherent dataset based on multiple sensors [3], in combination with FLUXNET in situ GPP observations to predict GPP at a global scale for a period of 30 years. VODCA2GPP exhibits similar spatial and temporal patterns as existing observation-based global GPP datasets from FLUXCOM and MODIS, but with a consistent positive bias. While VODCA2GPP reveals no significant global trend, it does show several regional trends, some of which corroborate trends found in the TRENDY model ensemble.&lt;/span&gt;&lt;span&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt; &lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt; &lt;p&gt;&lt;span&gt;Both datasets are available for free from open data repositories.&lt;/span&gt;&lt;span&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt; &lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt; &lt;p&gt;&lt;span&gt;[1]&amp;#160;Moesinger, L., Zotta, R.M., van der Schalie, R.,&amp;#160;Scanlon, T., de Jeu, R.A.M., Dorigo, W.&amp;#160;Monitoring Vegetation Condition using Microwave Remote Sensing: The Standardized Vegetation Optical Depth Index SVODI, in rev.&lt;/span&gt;&lt;span&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt; &lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt; &lt;p&gt;&lt;span&gt;[2] Wild, B., Teubner, I., Moesinger, L., Zotta, R.-M., Forkel, M., van der Schalie, R., Sitch, S., Dorigo, W. title: Weakly Supervised Learning for Pixel-Level Sea Ice Concentration Extraction Using AI4Arctic Sea Ice Challenge Dataset
abstract: High-resolution sea ice concentration (SIC) maps are critical to support various applications, e.g., climate modeling, ship navigation and activities in Northern communities. However, operational mapping of SIC based on expert annotations is coarse in spatial resolution and time-consuming to prepare. Although many convolutional neural networks (CNNs)-based methods have been proposed for automated sea ice mapping from synthetic aperture radar (SAR) imagery in recent years, the lack of pixel-based labels for model training hinders them from producing high resolution reliable mapping results. To overcome this challenge, this paper presents a novel weakly supervised learning approach that generates pixel-level SIC prediction using coarse region/polygon-level SIC ground truth. Specifically, a novel region-level loss function is designed to enable direct use of regional/polygon SIC values in ice charts for the training of a U-Net-based model. This avoids the errors in transferring region-level SIC values to pixel-level ground-truth SIC values effectively and allows the generation of pixel-level SIC and sea ice extent (SIE) estimates. The proposed approach is evaluated on the recently-published AI4Arctic Sea Ice Challenge Dataset with over 500 Sentinel-1 SAR scenes, ancillary data, and associated ice charts. The results demonstrate the effectiveness of the weakly supervised model in producing pixel-level high-resolution SIC maps that are consistent with ice-charts and visual interpretation.

survey reveals generic-level occurrence of scleractinian corals at reef slopes of Okinawa Islandhttps://doi.org/10.1098/rspb.2023.0026 Koki Nishitsuji, Tomofumi Nagata, Haruhi Narisoko, Megumi Kanai, Kanako Hisata, Chuya Shinzato and Noriyuki Satoh volume 290issue 1995Proceedings of the Royal Society B: Biological Sciences29 March 2023 Review history Review history is available via Web of Science at https://www.webofscience.com/api/gateway/wos/peer-review/10.1098/rspb.2023.0605 The shallow warm water coral reefs of the tropics and subtropics are rightly called the 'rainforests of the ocean' due to their incredibly high levels of biodiversity, hosting an estimated one-third of total marine species [1]. While our understanding of the general importance of these coral reefs as reservoirs of biodiversity is commonly accepted, attempts at quantifying how many species live in the oceans, or on coral reefs, is a much more complex question to answer. Our best attempts to put concrete numbers on total marine biodiversity have produced wildly discrepant numbers that differ by up to several orders of magnitude, depending on the methodology employed (e.g. compare [2] with [3]). Total coral reef biodiversity is a particularly obtuse problem, due to the inherently complex three-dimensional structure of these reefs [4] (figure 1a). The cracks and crevices of reefs produce space and microenvironments that can harbour multitudes of diverse organisms (figure 1b). Key to these ecosystems are the hermatypic corals themselves, largely zooxanthellate scleractinians (Cnidaria: Hexacorallia: Scleractinia), which via their symbioses with family Symbiodiniaceae zooxanthellae, produce the calcium carbonate structures that form reefs over time. Figure 1. (a) Overall landscape of a coral reef in Okinawa, southern Japan, with scleractinian corals and fishes visible, and (b) close-up three-dimensional structure of a coral reef in Okinawa, with green macroalgae, crustose coralline algae, turf algae, octocorals, zoantharians, scleractinian corals and foraminifers visible. Images: (a) = F.G., (b) = J.D.R.Download figureOpen in new tabDownload PowerPoint Comparatively speaking, we know a fair amount about the diversity of the reef-building scleractinian corals, due to their skeletal structures and the numerous features within, making taxonomy and the counting of coral species seemingly within our reach. However, these cnidarian groups have often remained taxonomically recalcitrant due to a myriad of reasons. Especially when viewed in situ or via photographs, coral identification can be a challenge, as microscale-skeletal structures often need to be examined to achieve reliable results. As they are ecosystem engineers, no ecological study of a coral reef is complete without coral abundance or diversity indices of some kind: scientists need to be able to count coral species and abundances effectively and accurately. These indices are the necessary foundation to investigate temporal changes and their causes and consequences. Ecologists can count corals via in situ observations, usually via SCUBA, which comes with a number of limitations, such as inherent risks, logistical effort, availability and accessible water depths. Other options that are becoming increasingly popular include remotely operated underwater vehicles (ROVs) or similar tools [5]. Sampling of coral colonies is another, invasive approach, but this is also time-consuming and damaging to reefs when performed at large scale, as well as limited in nature; one cannot sample every coral colony on a reef, and researchers' time underwater is limited by their air consumption. Alternately, transects or quadrats can generate two-dimensional photographic images that can later be analysed without time constraints [6], but these methods are often limited in resolution and neglect the three-dimensional nature of reefs. Three-dimensional photogrammetry methods solve this problem [7], but require large amounts of both computing power and time, and analyses are still limited to what the observer and their camera can see from above or outside of coral colonies, and cannot yet be applied at the wider scale of coral reefs. Environmental DNA (eDNA) applications therefore are ideal complements to traditional survey methods to increase detection rates and robustness of biodiversity monitoring. eDNA has the potential to non-invasively generate large amounts of marine biodiversity data [8], making it perfect for significantly improving our understanding of coral reef diversity. The first step of conducting an eDNA monitoring endeavour starts with the collection of an environmental medium that acts as source of eDNA. Sources thereby include water samples containing free DNA molecules or even whole organisms, mucus, faecal matter, gut contents or benthic sediment. The selection of source material can already influence the results, as benthic sediments and water samples can return different communities in the analyses, as well as the depth at which water samples were taken. Subsequent steps include processing and storage of the environmental samples, with the general consensus to process the samples as swiftly as possibly to prevent degradation of DNA molecules. Various protocols have been proposed for extracting DNA from environmental samples, but all generally seem to lead to satisfactory levels of DNA quantity and quality. Depending on the marker system used for amplification of the extracted DNA, single species can be focused on, or alternately even a whole community across a wide range of reef taxa with metabarcoding assays. While it may be sufficient to only detect positive PCR signals for single species confirmation, or investigate their abundance using quantitative PCR, DNA metabarcoding extends the principles of conventional molecular barcoding to mixed template samples using next-generation sequencing methods. Depending on the sequencing platform, thousands to millions of sequences are retrieved, which then need to undergo bioinformatic analyses. There are several potential ways described to process these sequences; all include quality filtering steps to exclude low quality, short, or erroneous reads. The result of the bioinformatic metabarcoding analyses usually consists of a list of sequences from all samples, which can then be compared with reference databases, resulting in a list of taxa that reflects the observed biodiversity of the eDNA sampling approach [8]. These results from eDNA studies have already helped to detect invasive, rare and cryptic species, as well as designate bioindicator species. On subtropical and tropical coral reefs, several eDNA studies have been already conducted, investigating coral diversity or even whole coral reef communities. Results so far indicate that eDNA applications can potentially be used to quantify coral cover, identify community differences within a reef system (e.g. lagoon versus reef slope), differentiate between communities along an anthropogenic stress gradient, as well as elucidate temporal patterns of coral spawning events [9–12]. The study of Nishitsuji et al. [13] demonstrates the successful large-scale use of eDNA to illuminate the scleractinian coral diversity around an entire island, Okinawa Island, southern Japan. The authors collected and examined eDNA from more than 60 locations around Okinawa Island, amplified mitochondrial marker sequences (12S ribosomal DNA) using a recently developed primer set [14] and compared their results with observations by divers at the same sites. Importantly, while both datasets were generally comparable, with similar results across sites, the eDNA dataset included more detected coral genera than the divers, and this was supported in statistical analyses. As well, the eDNA dataset included the first molecular records of at least two coral species or genera around Okinawa Island. Records and distributions form the bases of biodiversity data, and it is clear eDNA can contribute to enriching such important databases, highlighted by the detection of species not previously reported from the reefs of Okinawa. Additionally, the eDNA and diver-based datasets matched at approximately two-thirds of the sites, and at least a partial match was achieved at 91% of sites, cross-validating each method. However, which dataset should be followed when datasets do not match, as seen in two of the sites in Nishitsuji et al. [13]? This is a difficult question, and one that eDNA methodologies need to overcome. Is a diver-based assessment more reliable, perhaps due to varying primer sensitivity or mismatches [15]? Or are the eDNA data more reliable, revealing what the human diver eye cannot see? Given that most scleractinian corals should be relatively visible to the diving ecologist's eyes, it is probably very rare for eDNA methods to generate data for a coral that cannot be found with repeated focused dives. It should be noted this situation may not be applicable for other taxa that are smaller, more cryptic, or microbial. Thus, more investigation into comparisons between visual and eDNA datasets for a variety of taxa are needed to raise the reputation of eDNA methodologies for lay ecologists, as are the generation of more and different eDNA primer sets for corals or other targeted taxa. Given the exponentially increasing amount of genetic information available for marine taxa, such goals should be relatively easy to achieve and will also lay the foundation for research projects into the future. Finally, Nishitsuji et al.'s research is a welcome focus on the coral reefs of Okinawa and southern Japan [13]. It has long been recognized that the coral reefs in this region are not only comparably endemic and diverse, but also under high levels of threat due to their comparatively small area and rising anthropogenic pressures [16]. eDNA surveys and monitoring can help scientists in the region target areas for more in-depth surveys, and document biodiversity changes over time, as the extracted DNA, if stored correctly, can also serve as an archive of the biodiversity at the specific time point of the sampling. As well, amplification with marker systems targeting other marine taxa is still possible with the extracted DNA, which can help further elucidate previously unseen aspects of coral reefs. Furthermore, the successful use of eDNA for the investigation of shallow water reefs shows that this technique also has great potential for the investigation of mesophotic reef systems that are beyond the reach of SCUBA and can only be reached with increased technical effort. Can eDNA methodologies unlock biodiverse mysteries of coral reefs? Not alone. Cutting-edge technologies need a solid foundation, and eDNA is no different. The accuracy of eDNA depends on the accuracy and completeness of baseline data for target taxa, and thus cannot replace specimen-based taxonomy and biodiversity studies, which generate taxonomic frameworks and reference databases. The quality and reliability of eDNA monitoring results are thereby directly related to the quality and quantity of the available reference sequences. This can potentially lead to a large part of sequences recovered, be it amplicon sequence variants (OTUs) or operational taxonomic units (ASVs), that cannot be determined. Simply put, what is not part of a reference database cannot be found in eDNA analyses. In addition, databases may not be up to date with the latest taxonomy or may inadvertently contain incorrect information or misidentifications. These circumstances can lead to wrong taxonomic assignments in eDNA datasets. These problems can be common and often limit the integration potential of visual and eDNA data. In this context, the increasing reliance on eDNA methods in biomonitoring and marine ecology makes collection-based studies and biodiversity collections and well-curated repositories more important than ever, particularly given the rising extinction threats to our biodiversity in the Anthropocene. Scleractinian corals, unlike many marine taxa, represent an ideal group to work with in both visual surveys and with eDNA methodologies, and such studies can serve as templates for other taxa. More visual+eDNA studies similar to Nishitsuji et al. [13] across other taxa will help researchers expand and better integrate such datasets across the Tree of Life in the future. It is clear that eDNA offers massive potential to the future of coral reef ecology. While transects and imagery remain the de facto standard datasets in coral reef ecology, eDNA is being increasingly deployed, and the question as to which methodology paints a 'truer' picture of a reef is an open one. As well, what methodological approach best solves the needs of each study or conservation manager should be considered; often a rough idea of what diversity is present and how it changes in space and time may be enough for the question at hand. Both in situ diver-based and eDNA methods still have questions regarding taxonomic resolution, due to the above-mentioned issues regarding marine biodiversity (many coral reef animals remain undescribed) and taxonomy (scleractinian corals, for example, are undergoing revisions due to difficulties in often clearly delineating species boundaries). Additionally, mtDNA primers as used in Nishitsuji et al. [13] do not delineate to the species level for a range of coral taxa due to the conservative nature of mtDNA in most anthozoans [17], thus limiting potential for monitoring at such fine taxonomic resolution. Finally, as has been demonstrated in many studies [18,19], robust control sampling and measures to prevent contamination are always recommended to increase the reliability of results. Continued efforts to address all of these issues are needed alongside progress in eDNA methodologies. Regardless, eDNA represents a powerful tool for marine ecologists and coral reef science. As Nishitsuji et al. [13] have done, collecting and comparing imagery and eDNA datasets should become the standard for many studies in the near future, and we can envision a future in which eDNA data alone could be recognized as the most representative information of any given coral reef. Combined with imagery acquisition from underwater drones and ROVs [5], and streamlined AI-assisted imagery analyses [6], and the future of coral reef ecology and diversity studies will undoubtedly reveal major new discoveries. Progressive development of eDNA methodologies will lead to increasing incorporation of eDNA into the best practices for marine resource management and monitoring. The paper by Nishitsuji et al. [13] is an important step toward this exciting new future in coral reef ecology. Data accessibility This article has no additional data. title: A seamless coastal to global ocean pCO2 and pH reconstruction at a 0.25-degree resolution with extrapolation to the near future
abstract: Observational networks monitoring marine carbon variables are established to meet the critical need to estimate ocean CO2 uptake, as well as assessing its consequences on ocean health through changes in carbonate chemistry (ocean acidification). Despite considerable efforts over the past decades, data coverage is still sparse over large ocean regions, prompting the implementation of mapping methods to gap-fill carbon datasets over the globe. Different statistical approaches have been proposed with the aim to generate reconstructions of the complete marine CO2 system at high spatial-temporal resolutions. Following this goal, we first introduce a global reconstruction of surface ocean partial pressure of CO2 (pCO2) at monthly and 0.25-degree resolutions over the period 1985-2021. This high-resolution pCO2 product is derived from ensemble neural network models interpolating monthly gridded observation-based data from Surface Ocean CO2 ATlas (SOCAT). We will assess the ability of the proposed pCO2 ensemble (1) to derive long-term time series of pCO2 and associated 1-sigma uncertainty per 0.25-degree grid cell for each month, (2) to reproduce temporal and horizontal gradients of coastal pCO2 observations in comparison with a coarser spatial resolution, (3) to estimate surface ocean pH and air-sea CO2 fluxes. Furthermore, we will present an extension of the ensemble neural network models, which is referred to as a new module extrapolating pCO2 to several years ahead. The extended ensemble-based approach will ultimately be used to project global ocean CO2 uptake and ocean acidification with low latency.

title: Self-Supervised Contrastive Model for Flood Mapping and Monitoring on SAR Time-Series
abstract: Flooding is a natural disaster that has been increasing in recent years due to climate and land-use changes. Earth observations, such as Synthetic Aperture Radar (SAR) data, are valuable for assessing and mitigating the negative impacts of flooding. Cloud cover is highly correlated with flooding events, making SAR a preferable choice over optical data for flood mapping and monitoring.Traditional methods for flood mapping and monitoring using SAR data, such as otsu and CVA, can be affected by noise, false detections due to shadows and occlusions, and geometric distortions. While automatic thresholding can be effective with these methods, manual adjustment of the threshold is often required to produce an accurate change map.&#160;Supervised deep learning methods using large amounts of labeled data could potentially improve the accuracy of flood mapping and monitoring. We have a large amount of earth observation data, but the availability of labeled data is limited and labeling data is time-consuming and requires domain expertise. On the other hand, Supervised model training on small datasets causes severe generalizability issues when inference is taken on a new site.&#160;To address these challenges, we propose a novel self-supervised method for mapping and monitoring floods on Sentinel-1 SAR time-series data. We propose a probabilistic model trained on unlabeled data using self-supervised techniques, such as reconstruction and contrastive learning. The model is trained to learn the spatiotemporal features of the area. It monitors the changes by comparing the latent feature distribution at each time stamp and generates change maps to reflect the changes in the area.&#160;We also propose a framework for flood monitoring that continuously monitor the area using time series data. This framework automatically detects the change point i.e. when the major change started reflecting on available SAR data. Our continuous monitoring framework combined with a better temporal resolution (better than Sentinel-1) can potentially detect flood events in an early stage, allowing for more time for evacuation planning.&#160;The model is evaluated on nine recent flood events from &#8216;Mekong&#8217;, &#8216;Somalia&#8217;, &#8216;Scotland&#8217;, &#8216;Australia&#8217;, &#8216;Bosnia&#8217;, &#8216;Germany&#8217;, &#8216;Spain&#8217;, &#8216;Bolivia&#8217;, and &#8216;Slovakia&#8217; sites. We compared our results with traditional methods, and existing supervised and unsupervised methods. Our detailed evaluation indicates that our model is more accurate and generalizable to new sites. The model achieves an average Intersection Over Union (IoU) value of 70% and an F1 score of 81.14%, which are both higher than the scores of the previous best-performing method. Overall, our proposed model&#8217;s improvement range from 7-26% in terms of F1 and 8-31% in terms of IoU score.&#160;

title: Comparability of Deep Learning Techniques for Calving Front Segmentation in SAR Imagery
abstract: Monitoring glacier change processes leads to a better understanding of how glaciers respond to various external forcings. For sub-annual remote sensing, Synthetic Aperture Radar (SAR) imagery is indispensable, as polar night and cloud cover limit the temporal continuity of optical imagery. Especially with the launch of the Sentinel-1 mission, the availability of suitable SAR imagery has increased substantially. This high amount of data leads to another challenge: Manual inspection is no longer feasible. Therefore, in recent years, many studies applied deep learning to automate the segmentation of calving fronts in satellite imagery. To ensure comparability between different deep learning models, they must be trained and tested on the same data with a predefined test set and evaluated with the same metrics. A dataset intended to be used for this purpose is called a benchmark dataset and needs to provide the ready-to-use satellite imagery and the corresponding calving front labels. Gourmelon et al. [1] provide such a dataset for SAR imagery of calving fronts called CaFFe (https://doi.pangaea.de/10.1594/PANGAEA.940950). CaFFe includes multi-mission data (ERS-1/2, RADARSAT 1, Envisat, ALOS, Sentinel-1A/B, TerraSAR-X, and TanDEM-X), providing a spatial resolution between 6 and 20 meters and covering the period from 1996 to 2020. It contains images of seven glaciers from Antarctica to Greenland and Alaska. For each of the 681 images contained in the benchmark, two labels are provided: One displaying the calving front versus background and the other showing different zones (ocean, rock outcrops, glacier area, and no information available). CaFFe is split into a train set and a predefined out-of-sample test set, which comprises all images from two of the seven glaciers. A split of the train set into training and validation is not specified, as different approaches like cross-validation shall be possible. The benchmark covers a wide variety of different conditions to capture the variability of SAR calving front images. For example, images with open oceans and images with ice-melange-covered oceans are included in the dataset. Especially including images featuring ice-melange is of great importance, as deep learning models have shown difficulties in accurately segmenting calving fronts under this condition. Including images with ice-melange in the train set helps models to learn accurate predictions even under these circumstances. &#160;Adding such images to the test set ensures that evaluated models are able to cope with ice melange. The test set of CaFFe is specifically designed to be challenging, such that the generalizability of models to different conditions and spatial transferability even to other continents can be verified. Gourmelon et al. provide baselines (one for each of the available labels) complementing the benchmark dataset. Current collaborative work aims to evaluate recently published deep learning techniques for calving front extraction on CaFFe and compare it with the baselines.[1] N. Gourmelon, T. Seehaus, M. Braun, A. Maier, and V. Christlein: "Calving Fronts and Where to Find Them: A Benchmark Dataset and Methodology for Automatic Glacier Calving Front Extraction from SAR Imagery," Earth System Science Data, vol. 14, no. 9, pp. 4287-4313, 2022, doi: 10.5194/essd-14-4287-2022.

title: Microplastics – Global Scenario
abstract: Chapter 3 Microplastics – Global Scenario Majeti Narasimha Vara Prasad, Majeti Narasimha Vara Prasad School of Life Sciences, University of Hyderabad (an Institution of Eminence), Hyderabad, Telangana, IndiaSearch for more papers by this author Majeti Narasimha Vara Prasad, Majeti Narasimha Vara Prasad School of Life Sciences, University of Hyderabad (an Institution of Eminence), Hyderabad, Telangana, IndiaSearch for more papers by this author Book Editor(s):Meththika Vithanage, Meththika Vithanage University of Sri Jayewardenepura, Sri LankaSearch for more papers by this authorMajeti Narasimha Vara Prasad, Majeti Narasimha Vara Prasad University of Hyderabad (an Institution of Eminence), IndiaSearch for more papers by this author First published: 05 May 2023 https://doi.org/10.1002/9781119879534.ch3 AboutPDFPDF ToolsRequest permissionExport citationAdd to favoritesTrack citation ShareShare Summary Microplastics are emerging global contaminants and pollutants. There is growing interest in the scientific community on the subject of microplastics. This chapter focuses on the global scenario of microplastics as persistent contaminants in the environment. Recent advances in multidisciplinary research on microplastics, including distribution in the aerosphere, hydrosphere, and soil, as well as the sources, fate, distribution, toxicity, and management of microplastics, are covered in this chapter. Most microplastics are generated on land and end up in the marine environment. This chapter reviews the status of single-use plastics and microplastics in the aerosphere, aquatic environment, soil systems, and food chain and web, along with treatment technologies and management aspects. Sampling methods and treatment and analytical techniques used to identify microplastics in the triad of the environment are covered. Microplastics in beach and marine environments, leaching and adsorption, and microplastics from landfills and industrial wastewaters are appraised in the hydrosphere. Additionally, the presence of microplastics in sewage sludge and soils irrigated with wastewater or fertilized with sludge, as well as the possible effects on plants and human health, are discussed. Necessary strategies, including valuable resources for environmental researchers, ecologists and toxicologists, policymakers, and non-experts, are also covered. Macro- and molecular-level interactions of microplastics with the human, animal, and environmental domains of the triad are highlighted. title: Ecology of Lake Erie - Nutrients, microbes, algae, and dreissenid mussels: A synthesis
abstract: The Lake Erie ecosystem, including its physical, chemical, and biological components, has changed considerably during recent decades owing to human-induced environmental stress (Fraker et al., 2022; Makarewicz and Bertram, 1991; Munawar and Munawar, 1976; Sinclair et al., 2021). While much has been learned from monitoring and research activities, a full understanding of how and why the ecosystem has changed is lacking (Fraker et al., 2023; Fussell et al., 2016; Sterner et al., 2017; Scavia et al., 2023), which has hampered the development of management strategies that can help sustain the integrity of the lake and its valued ecosystem services (e.g. clean water, safe recreation, food production). This AEHM special issue is the first of four focused on Lake Erie, all of which will aim to display the science being conducted to enhance ecosystem understanding and guide management decision-making.This special issue centers on watershed, nutrient, microbial (including cyanobacteria), algal, and dreissenid mussel dynamics, including their causes and consequences. Specifically, it focuses on understanding factors that have driven changes in: 1) nutrient loading and in-lake nutrient dynamics; 2) algal and cyanobacteria dynamics; and 3) dreissenid growth, impacts, and spatial variation. After recapping each paper's major messages and management implications, we offer some concluding remarks.Since the early 2000s, Lake Erie has shown signs of intensified eutrophication, including increases in the extent and duration of hypoxia and harmful algal blooms dominated by cyanobacteria (hereafter, cyanoHABs; Scavia et al., 2014; Watson et al., 2016). Some of those symptoms have been linked to altered nutrient dynamics in Lake Erie's watersheds and, particularly, significant increases in dissolved reactive phosphorus loads (Baker et al., 2014; Stumpf et al., 2016). The source of most phosphorus entering Lake Erie is agriculture (Wilson et al., 2018); however, this source is dispersed across the landscape (Kast et al., 2021) and difficult to mitigate. Thus, delineating the characteristics of watersheds that export the largest amount of nutrients is important to identifying locations where nutrient reduction will be most effective. While reducing nutrient input is critical, the behavior of nutrients once they have entered the lake is likely to influence where and when cyanoHABs occur. Toward improving our understanding of eutrophication, two of this AEHM special issue's contributors focused on identifying causes of variation in the dynamics of nutrient loading and approaches to model the availability of these loads on chemicophysical conditions.Johnson et al. (2023) sought to identify how watershed characteristics have influenced nutrient and sediment inputs into western Lake Erie. To this end, these authors used a suite of physical attributes, land uses, and point-source contributions to characterize seven tributary watersheds, six of which are Great Lakes Water Quality Agreement Annex 4 priority watersheds, and five sub-watersheds. The authors then used principal components regression analysis to determine their relationship with nutrient and sediment yields into Lake Erie. Briefly, their results demonstrated spatial (regional) variation in contributions of nutrients and sediments from each river during 2017-2021 that was related to watershed attributes. For example, nutrient inputs into Lake Erie from watersheds were positively related to the percentage of land supporting cultivated crops and poorly drained soils, with higher slopes and lower amounts of pasture being positively correlated with sediment yields. These authors then discussed their findings in the context of impending nutrient reductions aimed at mitigation of Lake Erie's recent re-eutrophication (Baker et al., 2019), explaining how consideration of regional differences in nutrient and sediment yields could benefit nutrient management planning.While Johnson et al. centered on factors that influence nutrient and sediment loading into Lake Erie, Bocaniov et al. (2023) focused how nutrient (total phosphorus, TP) inputs affect within-lake TP movement and distribution. These authors used an updated phosphorus mass-balance model (2003-2016) to derive TP load-response relationships and response matrices to predict steady-state lake TP concentrations as a function of variable external TP inputs. A key finding is that inter-basin transfer of TP plays a large role in driving basin-specific TP concentrations (e.g. inflow from the central basin contributes ∼70% of the resident TP in the eastern basin). Bocaniov et al.'s modeling also demonstrated that western Lake Erie is likely to respond quickly (93 days) to reduced TP inputs, with longer response times estimated in the central and eastern basins (540 and 303 days, respectively). These authors then discuss how their findings can help guide where in the watershed to manage nutrients and what timeframes may be needed before agencies can expect to see impacts of nutrient abatement efforts.An outcome of excessive agricultural nutrient loading into aquatic ecosystems is enhanced primary production. Lake Erie has experienced increases in benthic algae (e.g. Cladophora), pelagic algae, and cyanobacteria during both past (1960s-1970s) and more recent eutrophication events (Munawar and Munawar, 1996; O'Donnell et al., 2023; Vollenweider et al., 1974; Watson et al., 2016). Lake Erie is a large and complex ecosystem, however, and the specific type or location of algal blooms cannot be predicted by nutrient loading alone. Rather, how and where blooms form will depend on complex processes such as gazing pressure and nutrient availability within the lake, as well as water warming that will interact with high nutrient availability. With this backdrop, four papers in this AEHM special issue sought to enhance our ability to understand and describe the dynamics of primary producers, including algae and cyanobacteria.To help better understand the mechanisms responsible for benthic Cladophora outbreaks in eastern Lake Erie since dreissenid mussels colonized the lake, Depew et al. (2023) quantified the enzymatically hydrolysable portion (EHP) of dissolved organic phosphorus (DOP). Samples were collected during May through September 2019 at varying depths along the north shore of the eastern basin. These authors found that the EHP substantially contributed to the dissolved P pool, with this contribution averaging 53% of the total dissolved P and 63% of the DOP concentration. Hence, a large amount of DOP appears bioavailable owing to enzymatic hydrolysis. This result, combined with the fact that bioavailable DOP concentrations often exceeded dissolved reactive P concentrations, indicates an increased role of the benthic contributions to P bioavailability in the eastern basin since the establishment of dreissenid mussels. In turn, Depew et al. highlight the need to consider EHP when designing management strategies to control Cladophora outbreaks in the eastern basin.In contrast to Depew et al., Hoffman et al. (2023) quantified seasonal nitrification in Lake Erie's water column and explored its potential role in driving microbial dynamics, including cyanoHABs dominated by Microcystis spp. To do so, these authors used the stable isotope, 15NH4+, to track nitrification and qPCR to determine the relative abundances of ammonia oxidizing organisms (i.e. bacteria and Archaea, AOO) during 2015-2017. Hoffman et al. found that nitrification rates were lower during cyanoHABs, suggesting that AOOs were not good competitors with cyanobacteria for ammonia. These low rates can in part explain why cyanoHABs dominated by Microcystis spp. (non-nitrogen fixers) can persist despite low bioavailable nitrogen (N). Further, the removal of bioavailable N via coupled nitrification-denitrification is lower than the increase in bioavailable N through regeneration and external N loading. Using these findings, Hoffman et al. discuss the importance of reducing N loading into Lake Erie as a means to help reduce seasonal cyanoHABs.Hounshell et al. (2023) also focused on understanding cyanoHAB dynamics, exploring the role of P as a driver instead of N. While total bioavailable P (TBP) loading from the Maumee River (Ohio, USA) during spring has been shown to be a strong predictor of cyanoHAB severity in western Lake Erie (Baker et al., 2014; Bertani et al., 2016; Stumpf et al., 2016), much unexplained variation in cyanoHAB severity remains. Thus, Hounshell et al. (2023) sought to identify environmental variables that could improve the predictive relationship between the Maumee River spring TBP load and cyanoHAB severity. Their modeling showed that at both low (< 273 MTA) and high (> 332 MTA) TBP loads levels, no other environmental factors improved predictive accuracy of cyanoHABs in western Lake Erie. However, during years with intermediate springtime TBP loads (273-332 MTA), predictions of cyanoHABs could be improved by considering winter and July TBP loads, as well as ice extent and phenology. While their work is still ongoing, Hounshell et al.'s research highlights the value of both tributary and in-lake monitoring, as well as process-based modeling to cyanoHAB forecasting.Wang et al. (2023) also sought to use modeling to predict the distribution of cyanoHABs in Lake Erie. Specifically, these authors compared the performance of the one-dimensional (1D) Aquatic Ecosystem Dynamics–General Lake Model (AED–GLM) and the three-dimensional (3D) Aquatic Ecosystem Model (AEM3D–iWQ) in predicting cyanoHABs, phytoplankton biomass (as measured by chlorophyll a), and associated physicochemical conditions (e.g. water temperature, nutrients), among other things, in western Lake Erie during 2008 and 2011-2014. By qualitatively comparing their results to in situ observations, Wang et al. showed that the 3D model better reproduced seasonal and spatial variation in nutrients and phytoplankton with less error than the 1D model. Conversely, cyanoHABs were better predicted by the 1D model. As detailed in their paper, Wang et al. explain how the scale at which these models are calibrated can drive differences in model performance. These authors also discuss the implications of their findings for choosing the appropriate model to support management endeavors, including how to best calibrate them to achieve desired goals.The final set of papers centered on invasive dreissenid mussels, which have become a ubiquitous part of the Great Lakes since their introduction nearly four decades ago (Nalepa et al., 2005). Owing to their potential to negatively impact native mussels (Schloesser et al., 2006), zooplankton communities (Johannsson et al., 2000), phytoplankton biomass (Bocaniov et al., 2014), and nutrient cycling (Hecky et al., 2004), Zebra (Dreissena polymorpha) and Quagga (D. rostiformis bugensis) Mussels have garnered the interest of researchers and management agencies alike. Much of this effort has been devoted to understanding the mechanisms that influence dreissenid demographics and impacts of the food web, which are the focus of the last set of papers in this AEHM special issue.To understand the growth dynamics of dreissenid mussels and their impact on phytoplankton in western Lake Erie, Carter et al. (2023) combined field surveys, in situ growth experiments, and laboratory excretion and grazing experiments. Their results, which are important in interpreting two of the remaining AEHM special issue papers, showed that dreissenid communities have lower clearance rates and excretion rates compared to previously reported rates. This understanding, combined with reduced dreissenid densities in Lake Erie during recent decades, led Carter et al. to conclude that the ability of dreissenids to compound the effect of eutrophication that causes cyanoHABs may be less than previously thought (e.g. Vanderploeg et al., 2009; but see Carrick et al., 2023 and Vanderploeg et al., 2023). Carter et al. (2023) acknowledge, however, that the impact of dreissenids could be locally high at times, owing to their patchy distribution across the basin. In turn, these authors stress the need for frequent, fine-scale benthic surveys, which could improve ability to understand and forecast the impacts of dreissenids on the ecosystem.Carrick et al. (2023) also sought to quantify the impact of dreissenid mussels on plankton assemblages (heterotrophs and phototrophs) in western Lake Erie. Using controlled experiments conducted monthly during May through October 2018, these authors show that dreissenids graze actively throughout the growing season, consuming nano-sized heterotrophic and phototrophic plankton (e.g. phototrophic cryptophytes, centric diatoms, and non-pigmented chrysomonads). By contrast, lower clearance rates of cyanobacteria (e.g. Microcystis spp.), dinoflagellates, and some colonial chlorophytes were observed. Carrick et al. further suggest that selective dreissenid grazing on "non-harmful" plankton species in the nanoplankton size range, combined with lower grazing rates on larger cyanobacteria and chlorophyte species, could contribute to western Lake Erie's cyanoHAB problem. Notably, the small-scale experimental results of Carrick et al. contrast those from Carter et al.'s (2023) field-based study. This discrepancy highlights the value of both experimental and field-based approaches, as well as the need to carefully consider the spatiotemporal context of the investigation, when to quantifying the role of dreissenid grazing as a secondary promoter (above nutrient loading) of cyanoHABs.Vanderploeg et al. (2023) also used an experimental approach to quantity the impacts of dreissenid mussel grazing on the phytoplankton community. Their experiments showed that grazing pressure on phytoplankton varied during May through October, with grazing on cryptophytes and diatoms being high during late May through early July. Despite cyanophytes dominating the phytoplankton beginning in late July, dreissenid grazing on them was non-existent or low. Interestingly, 16S rRNA gene-sequencing analyses showed a diverse cyanobacteria community with Planktothrix dominating during the spring and Cyanobium dominating most of the summer through fall. By contrast, Microcystis, which is largely thought to dominate cyanoHABs in Lake Erie, only dominated during late June. Further, Microcystis was preferentially rejected by Quagga Mussels relative to other cyanobacteria. Using these findings, Vanderploeg et al. draw a similar conclusion as Carrick et al. (2023) by suggesting that dreissenid grazing can favor specific cyanobacteria such as Microcystis. Importantly, however, the final effect of dreissenid grazing as a secondary promoter of cyanoHABS depends on the population density of dreissenids, which is currently low (Carter et al., 2023).In this special issue's final paper, Elgin et al. (2023) conducted an in situ study to quantify spatial variation in colonization potential, growth rates, and abundance of dreissenid mussels at two sites with contrasting water-column conditions in western Lake Erie. Despite finding comparable dreissenid colonization potential and growth between study sites, both on and in the experimental cages, Elgin et al. found fewer mussels in the surrounding sediment at the site nearer the Maumee River. These authors use this finding to conclude that water-column conditions appear to favor dreissenid settlement and growth on hard surfaces suspended above the substrate across the western basin, but that conditions on or near the substrate may inhibit mussel settling and growth. Elgin et al. eventually discuss how substrate-driven bottlenecks could inform our understanding of dreissenid recruitment and distribution, as well as nutrient dynamics, in western Lake Erie. These authors also suggest how better characterization of substrate conditions could support dreissenid control efforts.Owing to the impact of humans, the world's ecosystems have been experiencing dramatic change, which has threatened their structure, function, and dynamics, as well as their capacity to support services valued by society. The world's Great Lakes are no exception with these ecosystems being degraded by numerous anthropogenic stressors, including nutrient alteration (both eutrophication and oligotrophication), non-native species invasions, habitat destruction, and climate change, among many others (Allan et al., 2013; Jenny, 2020; Odada et al., 2003). The magnitude, multitude, and simultaneous nature of these stressors have in turn challenged both researchers seeking to understand the dynamics of these ecosystems and agencies charged with managing the valued natural resources (e.g. fish, wildlife) and other services (e.g. safe drinking water, recreational opportunities) that these ecosystems provide (Allan et al., 2013; Odada and Olago, 2006; Sterner et al., 2017). Such challenges highlight the need for continued research aimed at understanding the causes and consequences of anthropogenic change.While all the large lakes of the world have been altered by anthropogenic stress, Lake Erie is among the most degraded. Its susceptibility to anthropogenic stress is largely due to its small size, shallow depth, high connectivity via shipping, and large watershed that supports both large cities and agricultural production (Fraker et al, 2022; Ludsin et al., 2001; Reutter, 2019). Most relevant to this AEHM special issue, Lake Erie has shifted trophic states multiple times in response to human impacts and subsequent mitigation efforts. Prior to the 1950s, Lake Erie was primarily in a pre-industrial state of mesotrophy-oligotrophy and shifted to a state of hypertrophy-mesotrophy during the 1960s-1970s. During the 1980s-1990s, it shifted back to more mesotrophic conditions in response to both mitigation efforts designed to reduce point-source inputs of TP and the invasion of dreissenid mussels. Most recently (post 2000), Lake Erie returned to a more eutrophic state due to non-point source runoff of dissolved reactive phosphorus (Kane et al., 2014; Ludsin et al., 2001; Sinclair et al., 2023; Vollenweider et al., 1974). Concomitantly, Lake Erie has currently been experiencing increases in the magnitude and extent of both bottom hypoxia and cyanoHABs (Scavia et al., 2014; Watson et al., 2016), which are threatening: human health through cyanotoxin exposure (e.g. Francy et al., 2016; Wituszynski et al., 2017); fish populations and the fisheries that they support (e.g. Stone et al., 2020; Wolf et al., 2017); and the regional economy through effects on tourism and property values (Smith et al., 2019; Wolf et al., 2022). These threats have increased the need for the science necessary to make informed management decisions (Fraker et al., 2023; Fussell et al., 2016; Sterner et al., 2017; Scavia et al., 2023), which includes describing the current state of the Lake Erie ecosystem and understanding the causal mechanisms of recent ecosystem change.The contributions to this AEHM special issue have provided new insights into the drivers of nutrient inputs, in-lake nutrient concentrations, benthic algae (Cladophora), planktonic heterotrophs, microbial autotrophs (including cyanobacteria responsible for cyanoHABs), algae (e.g. diatoms, cryptophytes), and dreissenid mussels. Further, each study has provided information that could benefit management, whether it be ecological understanding that could support ecosystem modeling (e.g. quantifying dreissenid distributions and their impacts on grazing rates and nutrient excretion; Carter et al., 2023; Elgin et al., 2023) or tools that could support nutrient management decision-making (e.g. Bocaniov et al., 2023; Johnson et al, 2023), cyanoHAB severity (e.g. Carrick et al.,. 2023; Hounshell et al., 2023; Vanderploeg et al., 2023) or chemicophysical conditions, including algal and cyanobacteria biomass (e.g. Depew et al., 2023; Hoffman et al., 2023; Wang et al., 2023). While many additional messages can be found in the papers, collectively, three key conclusions can be made. First, findings from each of the three focal areas of this AEHM special issue highlight the need to consider fine spatial and/or temporal scales in both the watershed and the lake proper. Doing so offers a means to fully appreciate the complex array of processes driving the dynamics of Lake Erie's chemicophysical conditions and lower food web (e.g. primary producers, dreissenid mussels). Second, while the papers in this special issue showed the value of field-, laboratory-, and modeling-based research to describing, understanding, or predicting ecosystem conditions, they also pointed to challenges that can arise when integrating findings. For example, discrepancies can arise owing to studies being conducted in different settings (e.g. in the laboratory vs. in the field) or at different spatiotemporal scales (e.g. see Carrick et al., 2023; Carter et al., 2023; Vanderploeg et al., 2023). Finally, most papers demonstrated the need for continued and intensified monitoring (e.g. broader coverage at finer spatial and temporal scales), which will challenge agencies responsible for tracking ecosystem conditions. We expect, however, that continued improvement in our ability to cost-effectively monitor Lake Erie and its watershed via remote sensing technologies (Yang et al., 2022; Yin et al., 2021), combined with continually improving data-analytic approaches (e.g. machine and deep learning; Sun and Scanlon, 2019), will help agencies meet this challenge.While the research described in this AEHM special issue has addressed many knowledge gaps, many more remain. Our hope is that continued reporting of findings as part of this AEHM Ecology of Lake Erie series will increase our ability to understand and model the structure, function, and dynamics of the ecosystem. Such understanding and tools should facilitate our continued movement towards ecosystem-based management in the Great Lakes, which could help agencies rehabilitate the lake and sustainably manage its valued resources in the face of continued anthropogenic stress.We thank Ken Minns for providing helpful feedback on a previous version of this synthesis.

title: Parameterizing ocean vertical mixing using deep learning trained from high-resolution simulations
abstract: Ocean vertical mixing plays a fundamental role in phenomena such as upwelling of nutrient-rich deep waters, and is crucial for determining net primary productivity in the ocean [1]. Simulating vertical mixing requires careful consideration and ingenuity for stable execution, as vertical mixing is often turbulent. Direct Numerical Simulations, in which the Navier-Stokes equations are solved without a turbulence model, are not realistic due to the enormous computational complexity. Ocean General Circulation Models (OGCMs) have low resolution and cannot directly resolve small-scale turbulence such as vertical mixing. Consequently, OGCMs based on the Reynolds Averaged Navier-Stokes equations use turbulence parameterizations to model the effect of unresolved motions on the mean flow [2]. Although K-Profile Parameterization (KPP) is widely recognized as a method for parameterizing vertical mixing [3], recent advancements in machine learning have triggered active exploration of data-driven approaches to parameterization [4, 5]. This study aims to develop a novel vertical mixing parameterization method using deep learning. High-resolution simulation results (O(103) m) are used as training data for a neural network to estimate vertical diffusion and viscosity. These estimates are then used to parameterize fine-scale dynamics in a low-resolution simulation (O(104) m). The input parameters of the neural network are the state variables RL = (vL, &#952;L, SL)T, where vL is the flow velocity field, &#952;L is the potential temperature, and SL is the salinity. Here, the L and H subscripts will be used to indicate the low and high-resolution simulations. The output parameters are P = (&#954;h, Ah)T, where &#954;h and Ah are the estimated vertical diffusion and viscosities respectively. The loss function is defined as the mean squared error between the state variables of the high and low-resolution simulations RL&#8722;RH. Verification experiments for the proposed parameterization method are conducted for an idealized double-gyre configuration, which models western boundary currents such as the Gulf Stream in the North Atlantic Ocean. We confirm the performance and efficiency of the proposed method compared to traditional KPP for conducting high-resolution simulations at low computational cost. Acknowledgements This work used computational resources of supercomputer Fugaku provided by the RIKEN Center for Computational Science through the HPCI System Research Project (Project ID: hp230382). title: NASA NeMO-Net's Convolutional Neural Network: Mapping Marine Habitats with Spectrally Heterogeneous Remote Sensing Imagery
abstract: Recent advances in machine learning and computer vision have enabled increased automation in benthic habitat mapping through airborne and satellite remote sensing. Here, we applied deep learning and neural network architectures in NASA NeMO-Net, a novel neural multimodal observation and training network for global habitat mapping of shallow benthic tropical marine systems. These ecosystems, particularly coral reefs, are undergoing rapid changes as a result of increasing ocean temperatures, acidification, and pollution, among other stressors. Remote sensing from air and space has been the primary method in which changes are assessed within these important, often remote, ecosystems at a global scale. However, such global datasets often suffer from large spectral variances due to the time of observation, atmospheric effects, water column properties, and heterogeneous instruments and calibrations. To address these challenges, we developed an object-based fully convolutional network (FCN) to improve upon the spatial-spectral classification problem inherent in multimodal datasets. We showed that with training upon augmented data in conjunction with classical methods, such as K-nearest neighbors, we were able to achieve better overall classification and segmentation results. This suggests FCNs are able to effectively identify the relative applicable spectral and spatial spaces within an image, whereas pixel-based classical methods excel at classification within those identified spaces. Our spectrally invariant results, based on minimally preprocessed WorldView-2 and Planet satellite imagery, show a total accuracy of approximately 85% and 80%, respectively, over nine classes when trained and tested upon a chain of Fijian islands imaged under highly variable day-to-day spectral inputs.

title: Quantifying errors in observationally-based estimates of ocean carbon sink variability
abstract: Reducing uncertainty in the global carbon budget requires better quantification of ocean CO2 uptake and its temporal variability. Several methodologies for reconstructing air-sea CO2 exchange from sparse pCO2 observations indicate larger decadal variability than estimated using ocean models. We develop a new application of multiple Large Ensemble Earth system models to assess these reconstructions’ ability to estimate spatiotemporal variability. With our Large Ensemble Testbed, pCO2 fields from 25 ensemble members each of four independent Earth system models are subsampled as the observations and the reconstruction is performed as it would be with real- world observations. The power of a testbed is that the perfect reconstruction is known for each of the 100 original model fields; thus, reconstruction skill can be comprehensively assessed. We find that a commonly used neural-network approach can skillfully reconstruct air-sea CO2 fluxes when and where it is trained with sufficient data. Flux bias is low for the global mean and Northern Hemisphere, but can be regionally high in the Southern Hemisphere. The phase and amplitude of the seasonal cycle are accurately reconstructed outside of the tropics, but longer-term variations are reconstructed with only moderate skill. For Southern Ocean decadal variability, insufficient sampling leads to a 39% [15%:58%, interquartile range] overestimation of amplitude, and phasing is only moderately correlated with known truth (r=0.54 [0.46:0.63]). Globally, the amplitude of decadal variability is overestimated by 21% [3%:34%]. Machine learning, when supplied with sufficient data, can skillfully reconstruct ocean properties. However, data sparsity remains a fundamental limitation to quantification of decadal variability in the ocean carbon sink.

title: A new satellite-derived dataset for marine aquaculture areas in the China's coastal region
abstract: Abstract. China has witnessed extensive development of the marine aquaculture industry over recent years. However, such rapid and disordered expansion posed risks to coastal environment, economic development, and biodiversity protection. This study aimed to produce an accurate national-scale marine aquaculture map at a spatial resolution of 16 m, using a proposed deep convolution neural networks (CNNs) based model and applied it to satellite data from China's GF-1 sensor in an end-to-end way. The analyses used homogeneous CNNs to extract high-dimensional features from the input imagery and preserve information at full resolution. Then, a hierarchical cascade architecture was followed to capture multi-scale features and contextual information. This hierarchical cascade homogeneous neural network (HCHNet) was found to achieve better classification performance than current state-of-the-art models (FCN-32s, Deeplab V2, U-Net, and HCNet). The resulting marine aquaculture area map has an overall classification accuracy > 95 % (95.2 %–96.4, 95 % confidence interval). And marine aquaculture was found to cover a total area of ~1100 km2 (1096.8 km2–1110.6 km2, 95 % confidence interval) in China, of which more than 85 % are marine plant culture areas, with 87 % found in the Fujian, Shandong, Liaoning, and Jiangsu provinces. The results confirm the applicability and effectiveness of HCHNet when applied to GF-1 data, identifying notable spatial distributions of different marine aquaculture areas and supporting the sustainable management and ecological assessments of coastal resources at a national scale. The national-scale marine aquaculture map at 16 m spatial resolution is published in the Google Maps kmz File Format with georeferencing information at https://doi.org/10.5281/zenodo.3881612 (Fu et al., 2020).
